tossups.question: In Eastern Orthodox churches, a special seal called a sphragis (“sfrag-EESE”) is used to stamp this thing with an abbreviation of "Jesus Christ conquers." This thing, which is called prosphora in Orthodox churches, is presented on a diskos, also known as a paten. In the Catholic Church, the Agnus Dei is sung during the (*) Fraction Rite over this thing. In the Lord's Prayer, this thing is described by the unusual Greek word epiosious, which is sometimes translated as "super-substantial" but more often as "daily." In the Tridentine liturgy, the Latin words "Hoc est enim corpus meum," or "This is my body," is spoken over this thing to bless it. For 10 points, name this sacramental food that is taken along with wine during the Eucharist.
tossups.answer: bread [or the host; accept communion wafers; accept arton; accept Lamb or amnos; accept prosphora before it is read; accept body of Christ before "body" is read; prompt on Eucharist before it is read]

tossups.question: The slowness of phosphorescence is due to a transition that is forbidden due to requiring a change in this quantity. This quantity names a tensor-like object that is inverted after a 360-degree rotation. A set of two-by-two Hermitian matrices describing this quantity combines with the identity to span all real Hermitian matrices. Systems can be "para" or "ortho" based on the orientation of this quantity, which in a two-electron system can be (*) 0 or 1. Triplet and singlet states are named for the multiplicity of this quantity, which is the fourth quantum number for an electron. This quantity determines whether a particle is a fermion or boson. For 10 points, name this quantity, which is effectively intrinsic angular momentum.
tossups.answer: spin [do not accept or prompt on "angular momentum”]

tossups.question: A Marie Belloc Lowndes novel about this man was adapted into the early Alfred Hitchcock film The Lodger. Hallie Rubenhold's 2019 feminist history The Five pointedly does not focus on this man, instead providing biographies of women such as Polly Nichols. Patricia Cornwell put forth the dubious argument that Camden Town Group artist Walter Sickert is the true identity of this man, while Arthur Conan Doyle theorized this person was really a midwife named Jill. An (*) Alan Moore graphic novel is titled for the "From Hell" letter supposedly written by this man that was sent along with a human kidney to the chair of the Whitechapel Vigilance Committee. For 10 points, name this serial killer who terrorized London in the 1880s.
tossups.answer: Jack the Ripper [or Leather Apron; accept the Whitechapel Murderer before Whitechapel is mentioned; prompt on Jack]

tossups.question: A metaphor named for two of these objects was proposed by Arnold Geulincx to resolve the mind-body problem. A "gazing country man" knows only the "nominal essence" of a "great" one of these objects at Strasburg in a passage in John Locke's Essay Concerning Human Understanding. The workings of the solar system are compared to one of these objects in William Paley’s Natural (*) Theology. A 1986 book by Richard Dawkins criticizes a variant of the “argument from design” named for one of these objects, which was endorsed by Voltaire. In a common exposition of Deism, the universe is compared to one of these objects that a creator set in motion. For 10 points, name these devices for telling time.
tossups.answer: clocks [or watches; accept Blind watchmaker; prompt on timepieces]

tossups.question: Toronto's Gardiner Museum is devoted to works in this artistic medium, including Western examples of the kakiemon type of these works. Janet Gleeson's book The Arcanum chronicles Johann Friedrich Böttger’s (“BOOT-ger’s”) discovery of how to make high-quality works in this medium at Meissen. The French produced many works in this medium at Sèvres (“SEV-ruh”). Lower-quality faience works in this medium were named for the city of (*) Delft. By the 14th century, the most desirable works in this medium were partially made with cobalt blue by workers in the city of Jingdezhen (“jing-duh-jun”) and were uniquely suited to holding boiling water for tea. For 10 points, name this medium of many blue-and-white plates and dishes produced during the Ming dynasty.
tossups.answer: Chinese porcelain [or Chinese ceramics; of French porcelain; or pottery; or earthenware; of fine China; or stoneware; or bone china; or hard-paste porcelain; or soft-paste porcelain; or enameled porcelain; accept Meissen porcelain; accept Meissen ware before Meissen mentioned; prompt on enamelware]

tossups.question: A woman in a play by this author shouts, "May God strike you dead, you two-faced scorpion! You thorn in my flesh!" A girl in a play by this author is punished with her mother's cane for looking onto a porch where men drank lemonade following a mass. This author wrote a play in which Death is personified as a beggar woman and the Moon as a white-faced (*) woodcutter. A play by this author that opens on the funeral day of the title character's husband depicts the complicated love triangle between Pepe el Romano, Angustias, and Adela. For 10 points, name this Spanish playwright of The House of Bernarda Alba and Blood Wedding.
tossups.answer: Federico García Lorca

tossups.question: The CIA supported a private militia in this general group of people called the GOONs who worked for Dick Wilson. The rock band Creedence Clearwater Revival donated a boat to activists for these people during a protest where Richard Oakes's stepdaughter fell to her death. The rights of these people were boosted by the 1975 Boldt Decision, a case stemming from a fishing dispute. An activist group of these people opposed the 1956 Termination Act and killed two FBI agents in (*) Pine Ridge in the 1970s. In 1969, Alcatraz was occupied by an activist group founded by these people called AIM (“aim”). Some of these people walked to DC on the "Trail of Broken Treaties." For 10 points, name these people, most of whom today live in cities rather than on reservations.
tossups.answer: Native Americans [or American Indians; or Indigenous Americans; or Alaska Natives; accept AIM or American Indian Movement before mentioned; anti-prompt on Oglala people or Lakota people or people on the Pine Ridge Reservation]

tossups.question: A 70 kilodalton bacterial "housekeeping" protein required for this process is coded for by rpoD (“R-pod”) and is contained in every one of this process’s namesake holoenzymes. This process stalls at attenuator regions in intrinsic or rho-independent termination mechanisms due to hairpin formation. Start sites for this process are typically labelled with a negative number indicating how far upstream they are, such as a pair of bacterial consensus sequences located at (*) -10 and -35 nucleotides upstream. In eukaryotes, the products of this process are processed by the spliceosome to remove introns and are given a 5-prime cap and poly-A tail. For 10 points, name this process that produces mRNA from a DNA template.
tossups.answer: transcription [prompt on RNA synthesis or RNA polymerization]

tossups.question: One section of this book opens, "You would not believe, would you, / That I came from good Welsh stock?" Another section of this book describes a family as "He oxygen, she hydrogen, / Their son, a devastating fire." A woman in this book named after Margaret Fuller laments "I would have been as great as George Eliot" had she not married John Slack. This book's first poem describes a man who "babbles of the fish-frys of long ago… Of what (*) Abe Lincoln said / One time at Springfield." It opens with a section that asks, "Where are the clown, the boozer, the fighter… Where is Old Fiddler Jones?" In this book, 243 poems follow "The Hill." For 10 points, name this Edgar Lee Masters collection of epitaphs of a fictional Midwestern town.
tossups.answer: Spoon River Anthology

tossups.question: British workers in this profession often handled objects named for William Mulready and became more efficient after reforms proposed by Rowland Hill. Romans in this profession were given a diploma to use clabulae and were part of the Cursus publicus. In the Holy Roman Empire, people in this job reporting to Franz von Taxis wore badger skins and blew horns on arrival. In 1840, British workers in this profession no longer demanded payment on (*) receipt with the introduction of the Penny Black. Thomas De Quincey wrote an essay praising the fast-moving stagecoaches designed for people in this profession. For 10 points, British workers in what profession routinely check red pillar boxes to find parcels and stamped envelopes that need delivering?
tossups.answer: postal workers [or letter carriers; or couriers; or mail carrier; or mailmen; or post industry; or equivalents; prompt on messengers]

tossups.question: In 2013, 10 percent of voters in this country wrote "AC" on their ballots to indicate a desire to call a Constitutional Assembly to modify a 1990 constitution that locked in a right-wing veto. Demonstrators in this country often sing folk songs by the group Quilapayún (“kee-la-pa-YOON”). In 2019, protesters in the south of this country cut off the head of a statue of Pedro de Valdivia and replaced it with that of a (*) Mapuche fighter. Those protests in this country were sparked by a four-cent rise in metro fares in its capital, causing President Sebastian Piñera to declare a state of emergency later expanded to Valparaíso. For 10 points, ongoing anti-government riots have severely damaged what country's capital of Santiago?
tossups.answer: Chile [or Republic of Chile]

tossups.question: A character in this novel imagines calling Adam and Eve through telephones connected through umbilical cords by humorously remarking, "Put me on to Edenville. Aleph, alpha: nought, nought, one." A man in this novel ruminates on the "ineluctable modality of the visible" and calls God a "shout in the street" while speaking with the schoolmaster Mr. Deasy. This novel, which begins by describing a (*) "stately, plump" man who comes "from the stairwell bearing a bowl of lather," is comprised of chapters with names such as "Proteus" and "Telemachus." It ends with a stream-of-consciousness soliloquy in which Molly says, "yes I said yes I will Yes." Stephen Dedalus and Leopold Bloom appear in, for 10 points, what novel by James Joyce?
tossups.answer: Ulysses

tossups.question: Bonds between carbon and this element are described as agostic (“uh-GOSS-tick”) when they interact with a metal center. A moiety of only this element is the simplest one moved via a Wagner–Meerwein rearrangement. This element is soluble in many metals, allowing it to be stored within their crystal lattices. A spongy catalyst with lots of surface area for this element to absorb onto is (*) Raney nickel. The formation of the diatomic gas of this element is defined to have a standard reduction potential of zero. This element can be added to both sides of a double or triple bond to reduce its order by one. There are 2n + 2 atoms of this element for every n atoms of carbon in an alkane. For 10 points, name this lightest element, the first on the periodic table.
tossups.answer: hydrogen [or H; accept molecular hydrogen, hydrogen gas, H2, or H+; prompt on hydron]

tossups.question: As part of 1986’s Operation Blizzard, anti-communist protestors in this modern-day country were doused with water and dumped far from its capital to freeze to death. That revolt in this country was prompted by the transfer of power to Gennadiy Kolbin. It's not Ukraine, but Makash Tatimov has argued that this country's Asharshylyk famine killed 2 million people in the 1930s. 456 nuclear tests were conducted in this country, whose other ecological disasters include the (*) Virgin and Idle Lands Campaign that caused a body of water on its southern border to drastically shrink in size. Its Soviet-era capital is now named for longtime ruler Nursultan Nazarbayev. For 10 points, name this Central Asian country whose capital was once called Astana.
tossups.answer: Kazakhstan [or Republic of Kazakhstan]

tossups.question: Adjacent elements in a Tamari lattice are equal by the law of this property. F. W. Light names a test for this property that constructs pairs of Cayley tables. Alternativity is a weaker form of this property defined using two unique elements instead of three and is possessed by octonions (“ok-TOH-nee-ons”). The only 4D division algebra over the reals with this property is the (*) quaternions (“kwa-TUR-nee-ons”). Since closure is typically implied, identity, inverse, and this property are sufficient to define a group. Many operations with this property are also commutative, though exceptions include matrix multiplication. For 10 points, give this property that allows one to ignore parentheses in products since the quantity “a times b,” end quantity, times c, equals a times the quantity “b times c.”
tossups.answer: associativity [or associative property; accept law of associativity]

tossups.question: In this poem, a group of characters escape a flaming wax palace through an underground tunnel. A prince in this poem mistakes a glossy floor for a pond, then later falls into a pond he mistakes for a glossy floor. Near the end of this poem, a stray dog joins a family that is climbing a mountain to heaven. In this poem, a woman's clothes magically grow longer to prevent her disrobing after she loses a rigged (*) dice game. That woman, Draupadi, is the wife of five brothers in this poem. The main conflict in this poem is the Kurukshetra War, during which a hero's divine charioteer proclaims, "I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds." Arjuna speaks with Krishna during the Bhagavad Gita from, for 10 points, what Sanskrit epic?
tossups.answer: Mahābhārata [or Mahābhāratam]

tossups.question: A work using this technique has sports paraphernalia like a Cleveland Indians hat hanging above a sketch of a canoe. That work is Trade by Jaune (“jon”) Quick-to-See Smith. The artist's childhood home of Charlotte provided imagery for the Projections series in this genre by the leader of the Spiral movement, Romare Bearden. John McHale claimed that he actually created a work in this medium that premiered at the (*) This is Tomorrow exhibit. A work of Pop Art in this medium by Richard Hamilton features a bodybuilder holding a lollipop. Works in this medium such as Hannah Hoch’s (“hoke’s”) Cut with the Dada Kitchen Knife often draw from magazines and newspaper photographs. For 10 points, name this type of artwork where different images are pasted onto one canvas.
tossups.answer: collages [or photomontages; prompt on mixed media before Projections]

tossups.question: In 1912, a woman musician who was taught at an institution in this city collapsed during a competition performance, inspiring her to compete again the next year and win it. After refusing to take a pay cut, conductor Daniel Barenboim was fired by the managers of a "populist" opera house in this city before the venue's 1989 opening. In the 1980s, musicians from an institute based in this city impressed American audiences with newly devised instruments as part of the (*) Responses project. IRCAM is based in this city, where the largest concert hall in its Philharmonie is now named for the composer Pierre Boulez. For 10 points, Lili and Nadia Boulanger attended and taught at a Conservatory in what capital home to the Théâtre des Champs-Elysées?
tossups.answer: Paris, France

tossups.question: In a novel by this author, a change in relationship is signaled by the protagonist calling his lover a "good woman" instead of a "good girl." That man created by this author tells his lover that his index finger is what remembered her best after he gets off a train. Another man created by this author follows a small dancer who carries a large drum before learning she is just a teen. The protagonist feels the Milky Way flow through him at the end of a novel that this author abridged and made into one of his (*) "Palm-of-the-Hand Stories." This author of "The Izu Dancer" wrote a novel in which the self-proclaimed Western ballet expert Shimamura meets the geisha Komako in a hot springs town. For 10 points, name this Japanese Nobel laureate who wrote Snow Country.
tossups.answer: Yasunari Kawabata [accept names in either order]

tossups.question: They're not prisons, but the "last" one of these objects was the subject of a book written in the 1920s based on interviews with Cudjoe Lewis, but not published until 2018. William Elford illustrated the "plan and sections" of one of these objects, another of which is the subject of Zora Neale Hurston's book Barracoon. A court case named for one of these objects made Joseph Cinque a national celebrity and had a decision written by Joseph (*) Story. The Brooks Diagram depicting one of these objects also features a pleading man who asks, "Am I Not a Man and a Brother?" John Quincy Adams defended 35 men who rebelled on one of these objects called the Amistad. For 10 points, name these vessels that forcibly transported people across the Middle Passage.
tossups.answer: slave ships [or Guineamen; accept answers like ships or boats carrying enslaved people; prompt on ships carrying people; prompt on ships or boats or vessels or similar by asking “what did they transport?”]

tossups.question: One resident of this location once failed to gather food to give to a hungry pilgrim, and instead threw himself into a fire to feed him. In some accounts, another resident of this location is turned into a three-legged toad as a punishment for vanity.  After drinking an immortality potion from the Queen Mother of the West, the wife of the archer (*) Hou Yi (“ho YEE”) travels to this location. Home to the goddess Chang’e (“chong-UH”) and an immortal jade rabbit, this location is celebrated during the Mid-Autumn Festival. A Greek deity of this domain asks Zeus to put Endymion into an eternal sleep. A traditional Chinese “cake” filled with red bean paste is named after, for 10 points, what celestial object embodied by the Greek goddess Selene?
tossups.answer: the moon [prompt on the sky or heaven]

bonuses.leadin: One artifact found at this site has an image of a man with half-closed eyes wearing a robe with shell inlays. For 10 points each:
answers: seals [or cylinder seals; or roller stamps]
parts: Identify this UNESCO World Heritage Site whose highest central block contains a mudbrick Great Bath.
The robed male soapstone sculpture from Mohenjo-daro is one of the few works of art recovered from the long-lived civilization named for this South Asian river's valley.
The best evidence of the Indus Civilization's writing system comes from the thousands of these items, many of which have an animal on them. "Cylinder" examples are found throughout Mesopotamia.

bonuses.leadin: The first movement of this symphony opens with an eight-part canon whose first and last parts are in E Aeolian (“ay-OH-lee-in”), with the rest in 6 other modes. For 10 points each:
answers: Symphony of Sorrowful Songs [accept but do not otherwise reveal Henryk Górecki’s Symphony No. 3; or Górecki’s Third Symphony]
minimalism [or minimal music; accept holy minimalism]
parts: Name this 1976 symphony for soprano and orchestra by a Polish School composer. Each of its movements is based on a different text about Mary, the second of which was found on the wall of a Gestapo jail cell.
Henryk Górecki’s (“goo-RET-skee’s”) Symphony of Sorrowful Songs was given this number. Beethoven’s symphony of this number is nicknamed “Eroica.”
The Symphony of Sorrowful Songs exemplifies a type of this compositional style often called “holy” or “sacred.” Process music and phase music are considered subtypes of this musical style.

bonuses.leadin: The pseudonymous Charles Johnson wrote a 1724 book about people in this profession that remains a major influence on their perception today. For 10 points each:
answers: pirates [accept A General History of the Robberies and Murders of the most notorious Pyrates; prompt on sailors or criminals]
junks [or junco; or jonk; or jong; accept Southern junks]
parts: Name this profession practiced by people such as Mary Read and Anne Bonny. Members of this profession supposedly founded the colony of Libertalia in Madagascar.

One pirate profiled in Johnson's book is this Englishman, born Edward Teach, who captained the Queen Anne’s Revenge and blockaded what is now Charleston. His nickname derives from his prominent facial hair.
Female Chinese pirate Ching Shih once commanded over a thousand of these Chinese sailing vessels. Their square sails often had bamboo battens.

bonuses.leadin: Goodstein's States of Matter opens by noting that Boltzmann and Ehrenfest committed suicide before darkly joking, “now it is our turn to study” this subject. For 10 points each:
answers: statistical mechanics [or stat mech; accept statistical physics]
ergodic hypothesis [accept word forms such as ergodicity]
second law of thermodynamics [prompt on second law]
parts: Give this subfield of physics that uses probability distributions to analyze the behavior of microscopic systems. It was principally developed for use in thermodynamics.
Statistical mechanics often relies on this assumption that over a lengthy period of time, each accessible microstate of the system has an equal probability of being accessed.
Statistical mechanics can be used to explain this statement regarding systems tending to trend towards configurations with larger entropies.

bonuses.leadin: This poet lamented a “glimpse of a dream smouldering in a cave” after stating, in all caps, that “the eagles” and “the robbers” “descend on us.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Nigerian poet whose Path of Thunder includes “Elegy for Alto.” The anthology Don’t Let Him Die commemorates his passing in wartime Biafra.
“Elegy for Alto” was written for performance with this kind of instrument. Traditions surrounding hourglass-shaped “talking” examples of these instruments constitute a West African oral literature.
Okigbo likely inspired the character Okeoma, who stops writing poetry to fight in the Biafran War in Half of a Yellow Sun. That novel is by this author of Americanah.

bonuses.leadin: In the late Roman period, many small statues were made of a goddess named Tyche who personifies the concept of luck and good fortune for these entities. For 10 points each:
answers: cities [or towns; prompt on city walls]
parts: Identify these entities. Tyche and other goddesses sacred to these entities were often depicted wearing "mural crowns."
Tyche was also often pictured holding one of these objects, another of which Zeus accidentally broke off the goat Amaltheia.
In some accounts, Tyche is grouped with the three thousand nymphs sired by this Titan, the husband of Tethys.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about some British writers who wrote about pre-modern medical procedures.
answers: Fanny Burney [or Frances Burney; or Madame d'Arblay]
parts: This man described the removal of a bladder stone in one entry of his six-volume diary produced during the reign of Charles II that is invaluable to historians.
An 1812 letter by this author describes getting a mastectomy without anesthetics. The Reverend Arthur Villars eventually agrees to let his guardian marry Lord Orville in this author's novel Evelina.
Daniel Defoe presented a horrifying parade of women who died in childbirth in a section from his “journal”describing a year of one of these events in London in 1665.

bonuses.leadin: It’s not “consumption,” but one book defines the “conspicuous” form of this word as “the most conclusive evidence of pecuniary strength.” For 10 points each:
answers: leisure [accept Theory of the Leisure Class]
meritocracy [or word forms; accept Meritocracy Trap]
longitudinal study [or longitudinal survey; or panel study; or cohort study]
parts: Identify this word which names a class of people in the title of a Thorstein Veblen book.

Daniel Markovits has argued that a “trap” of this system has caused the wealthy to work more. A 1958 Michael Dunlop Young essay popularized this word for a system that supposedly rewards those who work the hardest.

The UK’s General Household Survey, one of these types of studies, examined leisure time. 268 Harvard graduates were tracked for 75 years in another of these studies that repeatedly measure the same variables on the same subjects.

bonuses.leadin: After this country’s independence in 1963, the UK set aside money to buy back land from its “White Highlands.” For 10 points each:
answers: Kenya [or Republic of Kenya] (The mountain is Mount Kenya.)
tea [accept black tea or green tea]
parts: Identify this country whose National Land Commission recently changed lease terms in an attempt to reclaim more white-owned land. This country is home to Africa’s second-tallest mountain.
Kenya’s White Highlands are well suited for growing the leaves used to make this beverage, which the British also introduced into Assam from China.
Kenya’s tea regions have the largest population of members of this religion in Africa. Six people were killed in a shooting in a temple for this religious faith in Oak Creek, Wisconsin, in 2012.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about how women have been treated unjustly in the sciences.
answers: abstracts [accept précis; accept more specific types of abstracts like structured abstracts; prompt on synopsis or summary or thesis; do not accept or prompt on “introductions”]
Marie Curie [or Marie Salomea Skłodowska Curie]
having a Wikipedia article [accept equivalents like being on Wikipedia]
parts: A 2013 study by Glynn et al. found that these parts of scientific papers were rated more favorably when male authors wrote about male-typed topics. Nature’s public website only includes this portion of articles when the articles are not open access.

This Polish-French discoverer of radium is the most prominent exception to the trend of women being overshadowed by their male partners, as she is better known than her Nobel Laureate husband and son-in-law.

It took winning the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physics for Donna Strickland to earn this distinction, which she was previously denied despite co-laureate Gérard Mourou receiving it in 2005. The “Women in Red” project aims to increase the number of women with this distinction.

bonuses.leadin: Stanley Cavell named his variety of moral perfectionism after this American philosopher. For 10 points each:
answers: Walden; or, Life in the Woods [accept The Senses of Walden]
parts: Name this American philosopher whose idea of the "Over-Soul" likely borrows from Eastern religions. In another essay, he advocated the viewpoint of a "transparent eye-ball."
Cavell's other work on transcendentalism includes an account of The Senses of this semi-philosophical book, written by Henry David Thoreau near a namesake pond.
Arthur Versluis posits that this "Buddha of the North" was another major influence on transcendentalist thought. This Scandinavian mystic recorded his visions in Heaven and Hell.

bonuses.leadin: This process was sometimes known as a Yankee Jacket, and it might be done in conjunction with applying excrement called "Hillsborough Paint." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this form of mob violence. Women would sometimes throw pillows out their windows in preparation for this process.
17 Wobblies were tarred and feathered in Tulsa in 1917. Four years later, this Tulsa neighborhood, nicknamed “Black Wall Street,” was destroyed in a race massacre.
Several Americans of this ethnicity were tarred and feathered during World War I. Also during the war, sauerkraut was renamed "liberty cabbage" due to prejudice against members of this ethnic group.

bonuses.leadin: In a play from this movement, the accountant Mr. Zero kills his boss, is tried and hanged, then operates the title device in the Elysian Fields. For 10 points each:
answers: American expressionism [accept word forms such as expressionists]
parts: Name this movement represented by Elmer Rice's The Adding Machine and Sophie Treadwell's Machinal. Despite the author's protests, The Hairy Ape and The Emperor Jones are considered part of this largely European art movement.
The late career of this author of The Emperor Jones includes the more realistic Long Day's Journey into Night.
O'Neill had actors in this trilogy employ mask-like facial expressions in a move away from his expressionistic use of masks. This cycle adapts the Oresteia of Aeschylus.

bonuses.leadin: In the Battle of Siffin, Muawiyah I’s (“moo-ah-WEE-yuh the first’s”) soldiers stuck Qur’an verses on their lances, forcing this man to enter an arbitration. For 10 points each:
answers: Ruhollah Khomeini [or Ayatollah Khomeini; do not accept or prompt on “Khamenei” or “Ali Khamenei”]
parts: Name this man who was assassinated in 661 CE in Kufa by Kharijites, a sect that repudiated him after he agreed to arbitration. This man is buried at his shrine in Najaf.
During a 14-year exile in Najaf, this modern Shia cleric developed the “guardianship of the jurist” doctrine, arguing a religious scholar should be a nation's supreme leader.
Khomeini ultimately implemented the “guardianship of the jurist” doctrine in this country’s theocratic constitution following its overthrow of the Shah during the Islamic Revolution.

bonuses.leadin: This practice is typically done on growth media on a petri dish. For 10 points each:
answers: cell culturing [or word forms such as cell culture]
hemolysis [or word forms such as hemolytic; accept descriptive answers indicating that they break down red blood cells]
parts: Name this process of growing cells in controlled conditions.

Cells are often maintained in a phosphate-buffer form of this solution due to its isotonicity and lack of toxicity towards cells. In hospitals, this substance is used in IV bags to maintain hydration.

Cells may be cultured on BAPs to detect if they exhibit this behavior. If they display the alpha form, the agar becomes dark green, its beta form results in a yellow background, and if it does not display it at all it is said to be gamma.

bonuses.leadin: One of the main purposes of artillery barrages in World War I was to “cut” this stuff that was littered throughout no-man’s land. For 10 points each:
answers: barbed wire [or razor wire; prompt on wire]
Portugal [or Portuguese Republic; or República Portuguesa; or Kingdom of Portugal]
Battle of Amiens [or Third Battle of Picardy]
parts: Identify this technology originally developed for fences in the American West.

The first use of barbed wire in combat may have been at the 1895 Battle of Magul, where colonial troops from this country withstood an attack from Maguiguana. This country established a “factory” at Malacca in 1511 and developed the caravel.
The deployment of over 500 tanks at this World War I battle, the first in the Hundred Days Offensive, helped break the war’s stalemate.

bonuses.leadin: The newly christened Love Is in the Bin was created when a painting of one of these objects partially self-destructed at a 2018 auction. For 10 points each:
answers: red balloons [or toy balloon; or party balloon; or helium balloon; do not accept or prompt on "hot air balloons"]
parts: Name the heart-shaped object held by a girl in that Banksy painting. A boy is followed around by a red one of these objects in a 1956 short film from France.

Mr. DOB, a character that appears in many works by an artist from this country, was made into a Thanksgiving Day Parade balloon. That artist from this country, Takashi Murakami, employs the superflat style.
This artist used a special mixture of air and helium to fill balloons for his Silver Clouds. A late self-portrait depicts this artist wearing a "Fright Wig."

bonuses.leadin: This model is typically truncated and shifted up rather than slowly tapering off at infinity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this surprisingly singly-eponymous model of intermolecular interactions whose repulsive term was chosen to be the square root of its attractive term.

This scientist showed that nonpolar molecules experienced forces that scale with distance to the negative sixth as part of his namesake dispersion force, which is considered part of the van der Waals force.

London derived dispersion forces with the multipole expansion, whose second term describes these systems. The classical explanation of dispersion relies on the formation of "instantaneous" examples of these systems.

bonuses.leadin: A Gaspare Murtola quote lends its name to a painting of this mythological creature. For 10 points each:
answers: Caravaggio [accept Michelangelo Merisi, Michele Angelo Merigi, or Amerigi]
Goliath's Head [or testa di Golia; prompt on Goliath by asking "which body part?"; prompt on head by asking "whose head?"]
parts: Name this gorgon whose decapitated snake-covered head was painted onto a shield by a Baroque artist.
This Baroque artist used his own likeness in that painting of Medusa. Judith stands at arm's length as she cuts off Holofernes head in another work by this male painter.

Caravaggio later used his own likeness to depict this specific object. This specific object is held aloft in that painting gifted to Scipione Borghese, possibly in exchange for being pardoned for murder.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about depictions of baking in the stories of Eastern Europe.
parts: Seeking retribution for his wife Elka’s infidelity, the title baker urinates into his town’s bread in this Nobel Laureate’s story “Gimpel the Fool.”

“Gimpel the Fool” draws on the folklore of this religion. This religion also was practiced by the author of the story “Cinnamon Shops,” Bruno Schulz, who was shot dead by a Gestapo officer while carrying a loaf of bread.

A group of pretzel-makers working in a cramped cellar idolize the young seamstress Tanya, but come to revile her after she is wooed by a womanizing soldier, in this author’s social realist story “Twenty-Six Men and a Girl.”

bonuses.leadin: This “not fast” piece may have been meant to mimic the mandolin, as implied by its dedication to “James Brown and his Mandolin Club.” For 10 points each:
answers: cake walks [accept prize walks; or chalk-line walks or walk-arounds]
parts: Name this “Two Step” piece that Marvin Hamlisch used as theme music for The Sting.
“The Entertainer” is in this genre pioneered by James Scott and Scott Joplin. The latter also wrote pieces in this genre called “Gladiolus” and “Maple Leaf.”
Ragtime was influenced by music for this earlier “plantation dance,” which was later named for the food given to the winning couple at a competition during Philadelphia’s Centennial Exposition.
